body:
`$env:OS` is a Windows-specific _system_ environment variable - it has nothing to do with PowerShell per se. 

Letting PowerShell define its own environment variables - which can affect any processes launched from a PowerShell session - should be avoided.

Instead, PowerShell Core already offers the _PowerShell-internal_ automatic `$IsWindows`, `$IsLinux` and `$IsMacOS` variables.

The only problematic aspect is that `$IsWindows` is not defined in _Windows PowerShell_.
(By contrast, given that undefined variables are "falsy", something like `if ($IsLinux)` and `if ($IsMacOS)` will work as expected in older versions - _unless_ `Set-StrictMode -Version 2` or higher is in effect).

Thus, you can use one of the following methods to detect running on _Windows_ in a backward-compatible fashion (both approaches work even with `Set-StrictMode -Version 2` or higher in effect:

```powershell
# Backward-compatible way to detect if code is running on Windows.
$runningOnWindows = $env:OS -eq 'Windows_NT'

# Alternative:
$runningOnWindows = -not (Test-Path variable:IsWindows) -or $IsWindows
```

Also note that - in PowerShell _Core_ only -  `$PSVersionTable` now has  a `[string]`-valued `.OS` property, though its value is _version-specific_ (and in the case of macOS you need to look for `Darwin`); for instance:

```powershell
# macOS
> $PSVersionTable.OS
Darwin 17.4.0 Darwin Kernel Version 17.4.0: Sun Dec 17 09:19:54 PST 2017; root:xnu-4570.41.2~1/RELEASE_X86_64

# Windows (PS Core)
> $PSVersionTable.OS
Microsoft Windows 10.0.15063

# Linux (Ubuntu 16.04)
> $PSVersionTable.OS
Linux 4.4.0-116-generic #140-Ubuntu SMP Mon Feb 12 21:23:04 UTC 2018
```
Thank you for the information then I will work with what I can.
